preface.title: Introduction
preface.para: This is technical reference documentation for the DocBook XSL Stylesheets; it documents (some of) the parameters, templates, and other elements of the stylesheets.

This reference describes each of the HTML Stylesheet parameters. These are the easily customizable parts of the stylesheet. If you want to specify an alternate value for one or more of these parameters, you can do so in a driver stylesheet.
For example, if you want to change the html.stylesheet to reference.css, you might create a driver stylesheet like this:
Naturally, you have to change the href attribute on <xsl:import> to point to docbook.xsl on your system. (Or chunk.xsl, if you're using chunking.)
This is not intended to be user documentation. It is provided for developers writing customization layers for the stylesheets, and for anyone who's interested in how it works.
Although I am trying to be thorough, this documentation is known to be incomplete. Don't forget to read the source, too :-)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Extension for admonition graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the extension to use on admonition graphics.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Path to admonition graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the path, probably relative to the directory where the HTML files are created, to the admonition graphics.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use graphics in admonitions?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), admonitions are presented in an alternate style that uses a graphic. Default graphics are provided in the distribution.

refnamediv.refpurpose: CSS style attributes for admonitions

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Specifies the value of the STYLE attribute that should be added to admonitions.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Indicates what column callouts appear in by default

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If a callout does not identify a column (for example, if it uses the linerange unit), it will appear in the default column.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Extension for callout graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the extension to use on callout graphics.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of the largest callout graphic

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If callout.graphics is non-zero, graphics are used to represent callout numbers. The value of callout.graphics.number.limit is the largest number for which a graphic exists. If the callout number exceeds this limit, the default presentation "(nnn)" will always be used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Path to callout graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the path, probably relative to the directory where the HTML files are created, to the callout graphics.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use graphics for callouts?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, callouts are presented with graphics (e.g., reverse-video circled numbers instead of "(1)", "(2)", etc.). Default graphics are provided in the distribution.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Present callout lists using a table?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The default presentation of CalloutLists uses an HTML DL. Some browsers don't align DLs very well if callout.graphics are used. With this option turned on, CalloutLists are presented in an HTML TABLE, which usually results in better alignment of the callout number with the callout description.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Number of the largest callout graphic

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If callout.unicode is non-zero, unicode characters are used to represent callout numbers. The value of callout.unicode.number.limit is the largest number for which a unicode character exists. If the callout number exceeds this limit, the default presentation "(nnn)" will always be used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: First Unicode character to use, decimal value.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If callout.graphics is zero and callout.unicode is non-zero, unicode characters are used to represent callout numbers. The value of callout.unicode.start.character is the decimal unicode value used for callout number one. Currently, only 10102 is supported in the stylesheets for this parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use Unicode characters rather than images for callouts.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The stylesheets can use either an image of the numbers one to ten, or the single Unicode character which represents the numeral, in white on a black background. Use this to select the Unicode character option.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable the callout extension

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The callouts extension processes areaset elements in ProgramListingCO and other text-based callout elements.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Background color for EBNF tables

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the background color for EBNF tables. No bgcolor attribute is output if ebnf.table.bgcolor is set to the null string. The default value matches the value used in recent online versions of the W3C's XML Spec productions.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Selects border on EBNF tables

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Selects the border on EBNF tables. If non-zero, the tables have borders, otherwise they don't.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Annotate the Table of Contents?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, TOCs will be annotated. At present, this just means that the RefPurpose of RefEntry TOC entries will be displayed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Separator between labels and titles in the ToC

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: String to use to seperate labels and title in a table of contents.

refnamediv.refpurpose: FIXME:

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: FIXME:

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should bridgehead elements appear in the TOC?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, bridgeheads appear in the TOC. Note that this option is not fully supported and may be removed in a future version of the stylesheets.

refnamediv.refpurpose: An explicit TOC to be used for the TOC

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The manual.toc identifies an explicit TOC that will be used for building the printed TOC.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Type of HTML list element to use for Tables of Contents

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: When an automatically generated Table of Contents (or List of Titles) is produced, this HTML element will be used to make the list.

refnamediv.refpurpose: How deep should recursive sections appear in the TOC?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Specifies the depth to which recursive sections should appear in the TOC.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Control generation of ToCs and LoTs

refsynopsisdiv.src:fragment: <xsl:param name="generate.toc"> appendix toc article toc book toc,figure,table,example,equation chapter toc part toc preface toc qandadiv toc qandaset toc reference toc section toc set toc </xsl:param>

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter has a structured value. It is a table of space-delimited path/value pairs. Each path identifies some element in the source document using a restricted subset of XPath (only the implicit child axis, no wildcards, no predicates). Paths can be either relative or absolute.
When processing a particular element, the stylesheets consult this table to determine if a ToC (or LoT(s)) should be generated.
For example, consider the entry:
This indicates that whenever a book is formatted, a Table Of Contents and a List of Figures should be generated. Similarly,

indicates that whenever a document that has a root of chapter is formatted, a Table of Contents should be generated. The entry chapter would match all chapters, but /chapter matches only chapter document elements.
Generally, the longest match wins. So, for example, if you want to distinguish articles in books from articles in parts, you could use these two entries:
Note that an article in a part can never match a book/article, so if you want nothing to be generated for articles in parts, you can simply leave that rule out.
If you want to leave the rule in, to make it explicit that you're turning something off, use the value nop. For example, the following entry disables ToCs and LoTs for articles:
Do not simply leave the word article in the file without a matching value. That'd be just begging the silly little path/value parser to get confused.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Control depth of TOC generation in sections

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The generate.section.toc.level parameter controls the depth of section in which TOCs will be generated. Note that this is related to, but not the same as toc.section.depth, which controls the depth to which TOC entries will be generated in a given TOC.
If, for example, generate.section.toc.level is 3, TOCs will be generated in first, second, and third level sections, but not in fourth level sections.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Do you want an index?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Specify if an index should be generated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Indicate which lines should be numbered

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If line numbering is enabled, everyNth line will be numbered.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable the line numbering extension

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, verbatim environments (elements that have the format='linespecific' notation attribute: address, literallayout, programlisting, screen, synopsis) that specify line numbering will have, surprise, line numbers.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify a separator between line numbers and lines

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The separator is inserted between line numbers and lines in the verbatim environment.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Indicates the width of line numbers

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If line numbering is enabled, line numbers will appear right justified in a field "width" characters wide.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable the table columns extension function

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The table columns extension function adjusts the widths of table columns in the HTML result to more accurately reflect the specifications in the CALS table.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable the textinsert extension element

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The textinsert extension element inserts the contents of a a file into the result tree (as text).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable extensions

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, extensions may be used. Each extension is further controlled by its own parameter. But if use.extensions is zero, no extensions will be used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are chapters automatically enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled chapters will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are Appendixes automatically enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled appendixes will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are parts and references enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled parts and references will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are prefaces enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled prefaces will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are divisions in QAndASets enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled qandadivs will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Are sections enumerated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), unlabeled sections will be enumerated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Do section labels include the component label?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), section labels are prefixed with the label of the component that contains them.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Renumber chapters in each part?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If label.from.part is non-zero, components (chapters, appendixes, etc.) will be numbered from 1 in each part. Otherwise, they will be numbered monotonically throughout each book.

refnamediv.refpurpose: An HTML base URI

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If html.base is set, it is used for the BASE element in the HEAD of the HTML documents. This is useful for dynamically served HTML where the base URI needs to be shifted.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The type of the stylesheet used in the generated HTML

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The type of the stylesheet to place in the HTML link tag.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of the stylesheet to use in the generated HTML

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The name of the stylesheet to place in the HTML LINK tag, or the empty string to suppress the stylesheet LINK.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use ID value of chunk elements as the filename?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If use.id.as.filename is non-zero, the filename of chunk elements that have IDs will be derived from the ID value.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable CSS decoration of elements

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If css.decoration is turned on, then HTML elements produced by the stylesheet may be decorated with STYLE attributes. For example, the LI tags produced for list items may include a fragment of CSS in the STYLE attribute which sets the CSS property "list-style-type".

refnamediv.refpurpose:
Insert additional

elements for spacing?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: When non-zero, additional, empty paragraphs are inserted in several contexts (for example, around informal figures), to create a more pleasing visual appearance in many browsers.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Pass emphasis role attribute through to HTML?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, the role attribute of emphasis elements will be passed through to the HTML as a class attribute on a span that surrounds the emphasis.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Pass phrase role attribute through to HTML?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, the role attribute of phrase elements will be passed through to the HTML as a class attribute on a span that surrounds the phrase.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should longdesc URIs be created?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, HTML files will be created for the longdesc attribute. These files are created from the textobjects in mediaobjects and inlinemediaobject.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should a link to the longdesc be included in the HTML?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, links will be created to the HTML files created for the longdesc attribute. It makes no sense to turn enable this option without also enabling the $html.longdesc parameter.
The longdesc.link named template is called to construct the link.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Attempt to make sure the HTML output is valid HTML

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If make.valid.html is true, the stylesheets take extra effort to ensure that the resulting HTML is valid. This may mean that some para tags are translated into HTML divs or that other substitutions occur.

This parameter is different from html.cleanup because it changes the resulting markup; it does not use extension functions to manipulate result-tree-fragments and is therefore applicable to any XSLT processor.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Attempt to clean up the resulting HTML?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, and if the EXSLT extensions are supported by your processor, the resulting HTML will be cleaned up. This improves the chances that the resulting HTML will be valid. It may also improve the formatting of some elements.
This parameter is different from make.valid.html because it uses extension functions to manipulate result-tree-fragments.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The URI of the image to be used for draft watermarks

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The image to be used for draft watermarks.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, the HTML stylesheet will generate ID attributes on containers. For example, the markup:
might produce:
The alternative is to generate anchors:
Because the name attribute of the a element and the id attribute of other tags are both of type ID, producing both generates invalid documents.
As of version 1.50, you can use this switch to control which type of identifier is generated. For backwards-compatibility, generating a anchors is preferred.
Note: at present, this switch is incompletely implemented. Disabling ID attributes will suppress them, but enabling ID attributes will not suppress the anchors.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify the root element to format

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If rootid is specified, it must be the value of an ID that occurs in the document being formatted. The entire document will be loaded and parsed, but formatting will begin at the element identified, rather than at the root. For example, this allows you to process only chapter 4 of a book.
Because the entire document is available to the processor, automatic numbering, cross references, and other dependencies are correctly resolved.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Disable header and footer navigation

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If suppress.navigation is turned on, header and footer navigation will be suppressed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Inherit keywords from ancestor elements?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If inherit.keywords is non-zero, the keyword META for each HTML HEAD element will include all of the keywords from ancestral elements. Otherwise, only the keywords from the current section will be used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Print single-year ranges (e.g., 1998-1999)

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, year ranges that span a single year will be printed in range notation (1998-1999) instead of discrete notation (1998, 1999).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Collate copyright years into ranges?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, copyright years will be collated into ranges.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Is othername in author a middle name?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), the othername of an author appears between the firstname and surname. Otherwise, othername is suppressed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: TBD

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: TBD

refnamediv.refpurpose: Decorate elements of a FuncSynopsis?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), elements of the FuncSynopsis will be decorated (e.g. bold or italic). The decoration is controlled by functions that can be redefined in a customization layer.

refnamediv.refpurpose: What style of 'FuncSynopsis' should be generated?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If funcsynopsis.style is ansi, ANSI-style function synopses are generated for a funcsynopsis, otherwise K&R-style function synopses are generated.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate parens after a function?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If not 0, the formatting of a function element will include generated parenthesis.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Output NAME header before 'RefName'(s)?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), a "NAME" section title is output before the list of 'RefName's. This parameter and refentry.generate.title are mutually exclusive.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Output title before 'RefName'(s)?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), the reference page title or first name is output before the list of 'RefName's. This parameter and refentry.generate.name are mutually exclusive.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Output manvolnum as part of refentry cross-reference?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: if true (non-zero), the manvolnum is used when cross-referencing refentrys, either with xref or citerefentry.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate URL links when cross-referencing RefEntrys?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, a web link will be generated, presumably to an online man->HTML gateway. The text of the link is generated by the generate.citerefentry.link template.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate a separator between consecutive RefEntry elements?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, a separator will be generated between consecutive reference pages.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The default width of tables

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If specified, this value will be used for the WIDTH attribute on tables that do not specify an alternate width (with the dbhtml processing instruction).

refnamediv.refpurpose: The (absolute) nominal width of tables

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: In order to convert CALS column widths into HTML column widths, it is sometimes necessary to have an absolute table width to use for conversion of mixed absolute and relative widths. This value must be an absolute length (not a percentag).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use CSS to specify table, row, and cell borders?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), CSS will be used to draw table borders.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Sets the default for defaultlabel on QandASet.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If no defaultlabel attribute is specified on a QandASet, this value is used. It must be one of the legal values for the defaultlabel attribute.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Does enumeration of QandASet components inherit the numeration of parent elements?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), numbered QandADiv elements and Questions and Answers inherit the numeration of the ancestors of the QandASet.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Mailto URL for the LINK REL=made HTML HEAD element

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If not the empty string, this address will be used for the REL=made LINK element in the HTML HEAD.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The HTML anchor target for ULinks

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If ulink.target is set, its value will be used for the target attribute on anchors generated for ulinks.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Names the fragment identifier portion of an OLink resolver query

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: The extension of OLink outline files

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Names the public identifier portion of an OLink resolver query

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Names the system identifier portion of an OLink resolver query

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: The root name of the OLink resolver (usually a script)

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Text to separate bibliography entries

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Text to separate bibliography entries

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of the bibliography collection file

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Maintaining bibliography entries across a set of documents is tedious, time consuming, and error prone. It makes much more sense, usually, to store all of the bibliography entries in a single place and simply extract the ones you need in each document.
That's the purpose of the bibliography.collection parameter. To setup a global bibliography database, follow these steps:

First, create a stand-alone bibliography document that contains all of the documents that you wish to reference. Make sure that each bibliography entry (whether you use biblioentry or bibliomixed) has an ID.
My global bibliography, ~/bibliography.xml begins like this:

informalexample.programlisting:
<!DOCTYPE bibliography PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.1.2//EN" "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.1.2/docbookx.dtd"> <bibliography><title>References</title>
<bibliomixed id="xml-rec"><abbrev>XML 1.0</abbrev>Tim Bray, Jean Paoli, C. M. Sperberg-McQueen, and Eve Maler, editors. <citetitle><ulink url="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml">Extensible Markup Language (XML) 1.0 Second Edition</ulink></citetitle>. World Wide Web Consortium, 2000. </bibliomixed>
<bibliomixed id="xml-names"><abbrev>Namespaces</abbrev>Tim Bray, Dave Hollander, and Andrew Layman, editors. <citetitle><ulink url="http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml-names/">Namespaces in XML</ulink></citetitle>. World Wide Web Consortium, 1999. </bibliomixed>
<!-- ... --> </bibliography>

refsect1.para: When you create a bibliography in your document, simply provide empty bibliomixed entries for each document that you wish to cite. Make sure that these elements have the same ID as the corresponding real entry in your global bibliography.
For example:

informalexample.programlisting:
<bibliography><title>Bibliography</title>
<bibliomixed id="xml-rec"/> <bibliomixed id="xml-names"/> <bibliomixed id="DKnuth86">Donald E. Knuth. <citetitle>Computers and Typesetting: Volume B, TeX: The Program</citetitle>. Addison-Wesley, 1986. ISBN 0-201-13437-3. </bibliomixed> <bibliomixed id="relaxng"/>
</bibliography>

refsect1.para: Note that it's perfectly acceptable to mix entries from your global bibliography with normal entries. You can use xref or other elements to cross-reference your bibliography entries in exactly the same way you do now.

Finally, when you are ready to format your document, simply set the bibliography.collection parameter (in either a customization layer or directly through your processor's interface) to point to your global bibliography.
The stylesheets will format the bibliography in your document as if all of the entries referenced appeared there literally.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate links from glossterm to glossentry automaticaly?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, a link will be automatically created from glossterm to glossentry for that glossary term. This is usefull when your glossterm names are consistent and you don't want to add links manually.
If there is linkend on glossterm then is used instead of autogeneration of link.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Does automatic glossterm linking only apply to firstterms?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true, only firstterms will be automatically linked to the glossary. If glossary linking is not enabled, this parameter has no effect.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of the glossary collection file

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Glossaries maintained independently across a set of documents are likely to become inconsistent unless considerable effort is expended to keep them in sync. It makes much more sense, usually, to store all of the glossary entries in a single place and simply extract the ones you need in each document.
That's the purpose of the glossary.collection parameter. To setup a global glossary database, follow these steps:

refsect2.title: Setting Up the Glossary Database
refsect2.para: First, create a stand-alone glossary document that contains all of the entries that you wish to reference. Make sure that each glossary entry has an ID.

informalexample.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!DOCTYPE glossary PUBLIC "-//OASIS//DTD DocBook XML V4.1.2//EN" "http://www.oasis-open.org/docbook/xml/4.1.2/docbookx.dtd"> <glossary> <glossaryinfo> <editor><firstname>Eric</firstname><surname>Raymond</surname></editor> <title>Jargon File 4.2.3 (abridged)</title> <releaseinfo>Just some test data</releaseinfo> </glossaryinfo>
<glossdiv><title>0</title>
<glossentry> <glossterm>0</glossterm> <glossdef> <para>Numeric zero, as opposed to the letter `O' (the 15th letter of the English alphabet). In their unmodified forms they look a lot alike, and various kluges invented to make them visually distinct have compounded the confusion. If your zero is center-dotted and letter-O is not, or if letter-O looks almost rectangular but zero looks more like an American football stood on end (or the reverse), you're probably looking at a modern character display (though the dotted zero seems to have originated as an option on IBM 3270 controllers). If your zero is slashed but letter-O is not, you're probably looking at an old-style ASCII graphic set descended from the default typewheel on the venerable ASR-33 Teletype (Scandinavians, for whom /O is a letter, curse this arrangement). (Interestingly, the slashed zero long predates computers; Florian Cajori's monumental "A History of Mathematical Notations" notes that it was used in the twelfth and thirteenth centuries.) If letter-O has a slash across it and the zero does not, your display is tuned for a very old convention used at IBM and a few other early mainframe makers (Scandinavians curse <emphasis>this</emphasis> arrangement even more, because it means two of their letters collide). Some Burroughs/Unisys equipment displays a zero with a <emphasis>reversed</emphasis> slash. Old CDC computers rendered letter O as an unbroken oval and 0 as an oval broken at upper right and lower left. And yet another convention common on early line printers left zero unornamented but added a tail or hook to the letter-O so that it resembled an inverted Q or cursive capital letter-O (this was endorsed by a draft ANSI standard for how to draw ASCII characters, but the final standard changed the distinguisher to a tick-mark in the upper-left corner). Are we sufficiently confused yet?</para> </glossdef> </glossentry>
<glossentry> <glossterm>1TBS</glossterm> <glossdef> <para role="accidence"> <phrase role="pronounce"></phrase> <phrase role="partsofspeach">n</phrase> </para> <para>The "One True Brace Style"</para> <glossseealso>indent style</glossseealso> </glossdef> </glossentry>
<!-- ... -->
</glossdiv>
<!-- ... -->
</glossary>

refsect2.title: Marking Up Glossary Terms
refsect2.para: That takes care of the glossary database, now you have to get the entries into your document. Unlike bibliography entries, which can be empty, creating placeholder glossary entries would be very tedious. So instead, support for glossary.collection relies on implicit linking.

In your source document, simply use firstterm and glossterm to identify the terms you wish to have included in the glossary. The stylesheets assume that you will either set the baseform attribute correctly, or that the content of the element exactly matches a term in your glossary.
If you're using a glossary.collection, don't make explicit links on the terms in your document.
So, in your document, you might write things like this:

informalexample.programlisting: <para>This is dummy text, without any real meaning. The point is simply to reference glossary terms like <glossterm>0</glossterm> and the <firstterm baseform="1TBS">One True Brace Style (1TBS)</firstterm>. The <glossterm>1TBS</glossterm>, as you can probably imagine, is a nearly religious issue.</para>

refsect2.para: If you set the firstterm.only.link parameter, only the terms marked with firstterm will be links. Otherwise, all the terms will be linked.

refsect2.title: Marking Up the Glossary
refsect2.para: The glossary itself has to be identified for the stylesheets. For lack of a better choice, the role is used. To identify the glossary as the target for automatic processing, set the role to auto. The title of this glossary (and any other information from the glossaryinfo that's rendered by your stylesheet) will be displayed, but the entries will come from the database.
Unfortunately, the glossary can't be empty, so you must put in at least one glossentry. The content of this entry is irrelevant, it will not be rendered:

informalexample.programlisting: <glossary role="auto"> <glossentry> <glossterm>Irrelevant</glossterm> <glossdef> <para>If you can see this, the document was processed incorrectly. Use the <parameter>glossary.collection</parameter> parameter.</para> </glossdef> </glossentry> </glossary>

refsect2.para: What about glossary divisions? If your glossary database has glossary divisions and your automatic glossary contains at least one glossdiv, the automic glossary will have divisions. If the glossdiv is missing from either location, no divisions will be rendered.
Glossary entries (and divisions, if appropriate) in the glossary will occur in precisely the order they occur in your database.

refsect2.title: Formatting the Document
refsect2.para: Finally, when you are ready to format your document, simply set the glossary.collection parameter (in either a customization layer or directly through your processor's interface) to point to your global glossary.
The stylesheets will format the glossary in your document as if all of the entries implicilty referenced appeared there literally.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Default extension for graphic filenames

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If a graphic or mediaobject includes a reference to a filename that does not include an extension, and the format attribute is unspecified, the default extension will be used.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Selects formal or informal procedures

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Formal procedures are numbered and always have a title.

refsynopsisdiv.src:fragment: <xsl:param name="formal.title.placement"> figure before example before equation before table before procedure before </xsl:param>

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Specifies where formal object titles should occur. For each formal object type (figure, example, equation, table, and procedure) you can specify either the keyword before or after.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Default punctuation character on a run-in-head

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Characters that count as punctuation on a run-in-head

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Display comment elements?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), comments will be displayed, otherwise they are suppressed. Comments here refers to the comment element, which will be renamed remark in DocBook V4.0, not XML comments (<-- like this -->) which are unavailable.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Enable decoration of elements that have a revisionflag

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If show.revisionflag is turned on, then the stylesheets may produce additional markup designed to allow a CSS stylesheet to highlight elements that have specific revisionflag settings.

The markup inserted will be usually be either a <span> or <div> with an appropriate class attribute. (The value of the class attribute will be the same as the value of the revisionflag attribute). In some contexts, for example tables, where extra markup would be structurally illegal, the class attribute will be added to the appropriate container element.

In general, the stylesheets only test for revisionflag in contexts where an importing stylesheet would have to redefine whole templates. Most of the revisionflag processing is expected to be done by another stylesheet, for example changebars.xsl.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should verbatim environments be shaded?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Properties that specify the style of shaded verbatim listings

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Punctuation after an honorific in a personal name.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter specifies the punctuation that should be added after an honorific in a personal name.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Format segmented lists as tables?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, segmentedlists will be formatted as tables.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Format variablelists as tables?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, variablelists will be formatted as tables.
This parameter only applys to the HTML transformations. In the FO case, proper list markup is robust enough to handle the formatting. But see also variablelist.as.blocks.

refnamediv.refpurpose: TeX notation used for equations

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If you want type math directly in TeX notation in equations, this parameter specifies notation used. Currently are supported two values -- plain and latex. Empty value means that you are not using TeX math at all.
Preferred way for including TeX alternative of math is inside of textobject element. Eg.:
If you are using graphic element, you can store TeX inside alt element:
If you want use this feature, you should process your FO with PassiveTeX, which only supports TeX math notation. When calling stylsheet, don't forget to specify also passivetex.extensions=1.
If you want equations in HTML, just process generated file tex-math-equations.tex by TeX or LaTeX. Then run dvi2bitmap program on result DVI file. You will get images for equations in your document.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of temporary file for generating images from equations

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Name of auxiliary file for TeX equations. This file can be processed by dvi2bitmap to get bitmap versions of equations for HTML output.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should be equations outputed for processing by TeX automatically surrounded by math mode delimiters

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: For compatibility with DSSSL based DBTeXMath from Allin Cottrell you should set this parameter to 0.

refnamediv.refpurpose: How many pixels are there per inch?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: When lengths are converted to pixels, this value is used to determine the size of a pixel. The default value is taken from the XSL Recommendation.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Specify the nominal size of an em-space in points

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: FIXME:

refnamediv.refpurpose: Allow SVG in the result tree?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, SVG will be considered an acceptable image format. SVG is passed through to the result tree, so correct rendering of the resulting diagram depends on the formatter (FO processor or web browser) that is used to process the output from the stylesheet.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Identifies the extension of generated HTML files

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The extension identified by html.ext will be used as the filename extension for chunks created by this stylesheet.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Toggle extra HTML head link information

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, extra link elements will be generated in the head of chunked HTML files. These extra links point to chapters, appendixes, sections, etc. as supported by the Site Navigation Bar in Mozilla 1.0 (as of CR1, at least).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Identifies the name of the root HTML file when chunking

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The root.filename is the base filename for the chunk created for the root of each document processed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: The base directory of chunks

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If specified, the base.dir identifies the output directory for chunks. (If not specified, the output directory is system dependent.)

refnamediv.refpurpose: Generate a manifest file?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, a list of HTML files generated by the stylesheet transformation is written to the file named by the manifest parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of manifest file

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The name of the file to which a manifest is written (if the value of the generate.manifest parameter is non-zero).

refnamediv.refpurpose: An explicit TOC to be used for chunking

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The chunk.toc identifies an explicit TOC that will be used for chunking. This parameter is only used by the chunktoc.xsl stylesheet (and customization layers built from it).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Depth to which sections should be chunked

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter sets the depth of section chunking.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Chunk the first top-level section?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If non-zero, a chunk will be created for the first top-level sect1 or section elements in each component. Otherwise, that section will be part of the chunk for its parent.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Omit the chunked filename messages.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If zero (the default), the XSL processor emits a message naming each separate chunk filename as it is being output. If nonzero, then the messages are suppressed.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Saxon character representation used in generated HTML pages

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This character representation is used in files generated by chunking stylesheet. If you want to suppress entity references for characters with direct representation in default.encoding, set this parameter to value native.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Encoding used in generated HTML pages

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This encoding is used in files generated by chunking stylesheet. Currently only Saxon is able to change output encoding.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Selects the output method for chunked documents.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of the temporary file used to hold chunking data

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Chunking is now a two-step process. The chunk.datafile is the name of the file used to hold the chunking data.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Use graphics in navigational headers and footers?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), the navigational headers and footers in chunked HTML are presented in an alternate style that uses graphical icons for Next, Previous, Up, and Home. Default graphics are provided in the distribution.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Extension for navigational graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the filename extension to use on navigational graphics used in the headers and footers of chunked HTML.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Path to navigational graphics

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Sets the path, probably relative to the directory where the HTML files are created, to the navigational graphics used in the headers and footers of chunked HTML.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Display titles in HTML headers and footers?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If true (non-zero), the headers and footers of chunked HTML display the titles of the next and previous chunks, along with the words 'Next' and 'Previous' (or the equivalent graphical icons if navig.graphics is true). If false (zero), then only the words 'Next' and 'Previous' (or the icons) are displayed.

partintro.para: Following parameters can be used for attribute value based profiling of your document. For more info about profiling look at http://docbook.sourceforge.net/projects/xsl/doc/tools/profiling.html.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for arch attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for condition attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for conformance attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for lang attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for os attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for revision attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for revisionflag attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for role attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for security attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for userlevel attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for vendor attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of user-specified profiling attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter is used in conjuction with profile.value.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Target profile for user-specified attribute

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: When you are using this parameter you must also specify name of profiling attribute with parameter profile.attribute.

Value of this parameter specifies profiles which should be included in the output. You can specify multiple profiles by separating them by semicolon. You can change separator character by profile.separator parameter.
This parameter has effect only when you are using profiling stylesheets (profile-docbook.xsl, profile-chunk.xsl, …) instead of normal ones (docbook.xsl, chunk.xsl, …).

refnamediv.refpurpose: Separator character for compound profile values

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Separator character for compound profile values.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Character encoding to use in files for HTML Help compiler.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: HTML Help Compiler is not UTF-8 aware, so you should always use apropriate single-byte encoding here.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should tree-like ToC use autonumbering feature?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If you want to include chapter and section numbers into ToC in the left panel, set this parameter to 1.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Filename of output HTML Help file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Change this parameter if you want different name of result CHM file than htmlhelp.chm.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Name of file with default topic

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Normally first chunk of document is displayed when you open HTML Help file. If you want to display another topic, simply set its filename by this parameter.
This is useful especially if you don't generate ToC in front of your document and you also hide root element in ToC. E.g.:
refsect1.programlisting: <xsl:param name="generate.book.toc" select="0"/> <xsl:param name="htmlhelp.hhc.show.root" select="0"/> <xsl:param name="htmlhelp.default.topic" select="'pr01.html'"/>

refnamediv.refpurpose: Filename of project file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Change this parameter if you want different name of project file than htmlhelp.hhp.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Filename of TOC file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Change this parameter if you want different name of TOC file than toc.hhc.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Additional content for project file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If you want to include some additional parameters into project file, store appropriate part of project file into this parameter.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should be paths to all used images added to project file?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: You should turn on this flag, if you insert images into your documents as external binary entities or if you are using absolute path in image names.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should be [MAP] and [ALIAS] section added to project file unconditionaly?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: You should turn on this flag, if you have your own alias.h and contex.h files and you want include reference to them in project file.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Filename of map file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Change this parameter if you want different name of map file than context.h.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Filename of map file.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Change this parameter if you want different name of map file than alias.h.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Depth of TOC for sections in a left pane.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Change this parameter if you want shallower ToC in a left pane of HTML Help viewer.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Should be entry for root element shown in ToC?

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: If set to 0, there will be no entry for root element in ToC. This is useful when you want provide user with expanded ToC as a default.

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: This parameter controls whether there should be folder-like icons (1) or book-like icons (0) in ToC.

refnamediv.refpurpose: Title of HTML Help

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Content of this parameter will be used as a title for generated HTML Help. If empty, title will be automatically taken from document.

appendix.title: The Stylesheet
appendix.para: The param.xsl stylesheet is just a wrapper around all these parameters.
appendix.src:fragment:
<!-- This file is generated from param.xweb; do not edit this file! -->
<xsl:stylesheet xmlns:xsl="http://www.w3.org/1999/XSL/Transform" exclude-result-prefixes="src" version="1.0">
<!-- ******************************************************************** $Id: param.xweb,v 1.42 2002/05/23 12:58:31 nwalsh Exp $ ********************************************************************
This file is part of the XSL DocBook Stylesheet distribution. See ../README or http://nwalsh.com/docbook/xsl/ for copyright and other information.
******************************************************************** -->
</xsl:stylesheet>
